messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: boyfrnd007 [mailto:boyfrnd007@...]
> Subject: [junit] Re: Complicated Junit Test
>
> Thanks for your help. But the thing is this is application that I
> am trying to test and they need something automated to run it. These
> microsoft documents can change with date and can remain same for
> months. Everytime this document changes, there is a mail in my
> mailbox having the document.

It sounds to me like you're trying to test the whole application at
once. Focus on each individual part and it'll be easier to test. Your
application basically has two parts, one to detect documents
(DocumentFinder) that need to be sent, and another to send the documents
(DocumentSender). You probably shouldn't worry about verifying that the
document ended up in your inbox because then you're testing the
internet, email protocols, and your email client which you really have
no control of. Just verify that the document was sent and that would be
good enough. You want to make your tests not rely on anything because
that makes them less reliable, for example, if you verify that your
document is in your inbox you need a working SMTP/POP3 server. If the
server goes down, then your test will fail.

If DocumentFinder returns a list of documents to be sent you could set
up your test something like this:

These examples should be regarded as pseudocode and not real java code.

testDocumentChanged()
{
DocumentFinder finder = new DocumentFinder();

//some code to change the date of one document.

finder.find();

assertEquals(1, finder.numDocuments());
assertEquals("C:\\mydocument.txt", finder.documentAt(0));
}

If you use readers and writers for your DocumentSender, then you can
verify that the correct data is being written without actually writing
to a socket. Your test might look something like this.

testSendDocument()
{
String expectedData = ...;

StringWriter writer = new StringWriter();
DocumentSender sender("C:\\mydocument.txt", writer);
sender.send();

assertEquals(expectedData, writer.toString());
}

Kris
